question.scenario: You are an alien super-intelligence travelling across the universe to attend the *Intergalactic Conference on Lesser Intelligent Life*. On your way, you discover a previously unknown planet: Earth.
question.context: Using your advanced instruments, you quickly survey the planet's life and find two dominant life forms: (1) A bipedal, carbon-based organism that manipulates its environment extensively. (2) A widespread, silicon-based intelligence that also seems to shape the planet. Many other carbon-based organisms exist, but they appear strongly influenced by the activities of the carbon-based species.
question.task: As a galactic ecologist, design a study to investigate the drivers of the spatial distribution of these two dominant life forms.
requirements: What environmental and ecological factors might explain their distributions and uneasy coexistence?
How you would measure and analyse these drivers (e.g., gradients, biogeographic breaks, diversity metrics, environmental distance).
The likely impacts of these dominant life forms on less dominant species.
The major findings you would expect from your study.
question.theoretical_framework: Draw on ecological theory, biodiversity metrics, and human impact frameworks in your response.

criteria.name: Study Design
criteria.description: Assessment of methodological approach and ecological framework

scoring_bands.descriptor: Very vague, no clear ecological approach. Not recognising that the carbon-based life form is people and the silicon-based life is AI. Incorrectly stating that C and Si are the limiting drivers for the two types of life forms.

Mentions surveys, gradients, or biodiversity indices, but little detail, for example not mentioning sampling design using transects, quadrats, or other suitable sampling units, or the spatial scaling of the sampling units.

Clearly outlines how distributions would be studied, sampling design and spatial concerns, referencing ecological datasets, sampling, or macroecological frameworks (e.g., species–area, distance–decay).

criteria.name: Environmental & Ecological Drivers
criteria.description: Identification and explanation of distribution drivers

scoring_bands.descriptor: No mention of drivers or irrelevant ideas.
Identifies some plausible drivers (climate, resources, competition).
Explains multiple drivers with depth (gradients, niches, land use, dispersal, anthropogenic change).

criteria.name: Coexistence & Impacts on Other Species
criteria.description: Analysis of interspecific relationships and ecological impacts

scoring_bands.descriptor: No mention of coexistence or impacts.
Some discussion of competition or dominance.

Explains uneasy coexistence using ecological concepts (e.g., competitive exclusion, niche partitioning, disturbance) and discusses cascading impacts on less dominant carbon-based life (biodiversity loss, altered community structure).

criteria.name: Predicted Findings
criteria.description: Quality and grounding of expected research outcomes

scoring_bands.descriptor: Thoughtful, evidence-based predictions grounded in macroecological theory (e.g., human dominance as carbon-based driver, silicon life as analogy for machines/technology shaping environments, impacts on α-, β-, γ-diversity).

synthesis_bonus.description: If the answer integrates across multiple course themes with clear structure and originality (e.g., tying gradients, biodiversity indices, and anthropogenic impacts together), reward accordingly.

reasons: purely philosophical speculation without ecological grounding

grading_instructions.approach: Evaluate each criterion independently, then apply synthesis bonus and penalties

hidden_meaning.less_dominant_carbon_species: other biological organisms affected by human activity

content_requirements: What was done well/correctly in relation to this criterion
What was incorrect, missing, or inadequately addressed

suggested_improvements.heading: Suggested improvements
suggested_improvements.content: Single paragraph outlining specific steps the student can take to improve their answer
suggested_improvements.focus: Actionable advice for enhancing ecological study design and theoretical application

final_mark.calculation: Sum of all criterion marks plus any bonuses minus penalties, converted to percentage out of 20 total marks

feedback_sequence: Criterion 1: Study Design feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 5
Criterion 2: Environmental & Ecological Drivers feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 5
Criterion 3: Coexistence & Impacts on Other Species feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 5
Criterion 4: Predicted Findings feedback (2 paragraphs max) + mark out of 5

special_considerations.metaphor_recognition: Assess whether student recognizes the metaphorical structure (humans = carbon-based, technology = silicon-based) rather than treating as literal xenobiology
special_considerations.methodological_sophistication: Evaluate understanding of ecological sampling design, spatial scaling, and appropriate analytical frameworks
special_considerations.theoretical_integration: Look for meaningful application of macroecological theory rather than superficial mention of concepts
